How four years of war in Ukraine redefined the European Union
subhead: With Russia's aggression against Ukraine, the world that saw the construction of EU has all but disappeared. The 27 member states belatedly recognized that peace was 'no longer a given in Europe,' and awoke to their military weakness and energy dependence.

In China, a Ming dynasty painting donated to a major museum resurfaces at auction
subhead: A masterpiece from the Nanjing Museum, donated by the family of a renowned collector, recently appeared at an auction, reigniting debate over the management of public collections.

title: Tears and stunned silence at vigil for Swiss fire victims
subhead: President Guy Parmelin described the fire as 'one of the worst tragedies that our country has experienced.' Around 40 people were killed and 115 were injured, including at least two French citizens.

title: Dry January's lasting benefits win over more and more participants
subhead: The challenge, which involves taking a break from drinking alcohol for one month, brings numerous health benefits. As proof of its success, alcohol-free initiatives are gaining ground.

title: Why France still struggles to protect domestic violence victims
subhead: More than six years after the round tables on domestic violence – organized to improve prevention, detection and punishment of abuse – advocacy groups warn that the system is now at a breaking point.

'I did it for the money, but I wasn't proud': Parties that hire 'dwarves' for entertainment
subhead: Hiring women or men of short stature to 'spice up' parties has become increasingly common in Europe in recent years. These practices raise both moral and legal questions.

title: 'We went through hell': Sudan's capital Khartoum slowly comes back to life
subhead: War in Sudan: A Trapped Nation (2/6). After serving as the civil war's frontline for two years, Khartoum was retaken by the official army in March. Since then, the city has been struggling to rise from its ashes.

title: Iran's protests led by shopkeepers is shaking up the regime
subhead: The collapse of the rial currency deepens the economic struggles faced by retailers, who have taken to the streets in several major cities. Some universities in Tehran have also joined the mobilization, as economic grievances merge with increasingly political slogans.
